cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

be marked Via Eastern.

div.head: IN HIS BRITANNIC MAJESTY'S CONSULAR COURT AT ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: VINCENT LOSCO BEY, DECEASED.

PURSUANT to Act of Parliament 22nd and 23rd Vic. Ch. 35 Sec. 29 NOTICE is hereby given that the creditors of VINCENT Losco Bey late of Alexandria deceased who died intestate on or about the 15th day of December 1904 and letters of Administration were granted on the 23rd day of March 1905 by the above mentioned Court to KETTY BALLY and HECTOR LOSCo jointly are required to send in particulars of their claims to the undersigned advocate of the said administrators within thirty days from the date hereof after which the said administrators will proceed to distribute the assets of the deceased having regard only to the claims of which they shall then have notice and will not be liable for the assets so distributed to any person of whose claims they shall not then have thus received notice. Dated this 10th day of April 1905. M. A. CALOYANNI,
Barrister-at-Law.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: SUBSCRIPTIONS.-Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber's address) P.T. 231½ per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½ (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.)
N.B.-Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.-P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
SUBSCRIPTIONS and ADVERTISEMENTS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria.
London Offices: 36, New Broad-street. E.C.
THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE" IS PRINTED ON PAPER MANUFACTURED AND SUPPLIED BY THE LONDON PAPER MILLS CO., LIMITED. (SALES OFFICE: 27, CANNON STREET, EC.)

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880.
Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
TUESDAY, APRIL 11, 1905..

div.head: THE BUDGET.
div.p: The Home Government has been lucky in obtaining a Budget surplus, for if a deficit had had to be faced, necessitating additional taxation, it would have provided the Opposition with the proverbial last straw wherewith to break the back of the Government majority. Now at the Forthcoming General Election its supporters will be able at any rate to point out to the electors that something has been done to secure a "Free Breakfast Table" by reducing the tea tax. The greatest disappointment, however, in the Chancellor's Budget speech last night will be caused by the announcement that the income tax is to remain unchanged, and the fact that the Government has not seen its way to listen to the overwhelmingly strong claims which the income tax payer has for relief, will make hosts of its supporters among the professional and middle classes very listless in the coming electoral struggle.

The additional revenue in the year just closed is clearly accounted for by the increased taxation imposed by the last Budget, and when we come to examine the figures, we find that the increase is very largely due to the Income-tax payers, who have again come to the rescue of the Government. Indeed, had this not been the case the Chancellor of the Exchequer would have had to face a deficiency, for not only did Customs, Excise, and Estate Duty realise about £1,900,000 less than the estimate, but a supplementary credit of nearly half a million for the Somaliland Expedition had to be added to the expenditrue of the past year. The two items which, together, have produced £1,840,000 beyond estimate, are Income-tax, which is responsible for £1,250,000 of this sum, and Stamps for the balance of £590,000. The increase under the latter heading is much the more satisfactory of the two, for it undoubtedly means that business is improving, and that contracts of all sorts are being entered upon in larger measure than in the previous year. The increased receipts from Income-tax are almost wholly due, we imagine, to the extra pressure put upon the taxpayer to secure payment of the impost in every case before the year closed. In other words, the increased yield is very largely made up of the contributions of those who are usually in arrears when the national accounts are made up, but who this year have been coaxed or harried into earlier payment. This, of course, will be an important element in the revenue calculations for the ensuing year, for even Chancellors of the Exchequer cannot have their cake and eat it too. The falling off in Customs and Excise will be viewed with different feelings, according to the standpoints of individuals. The temperance party-or rather we should say the teetotalers, for all sensible men are for temperance except the intemperate total abolitionist-will rejoice that Excise shows a reduction below estimate of three-quarters of a million. This means a considerably less national "drink bill" than formerly, and, indeed, it is common knowledge that we are reducing our consumption of ordinary alcoholic liquors.

div.head: MESOPOTAMIA.
div.p: During the past few days we have published the beginning of Sir Wm. Willcock's report on Mesopotamia, which gives a description of the Euphrates and Tigris Rivers. It will be evident to the most casual reader that the Turkish Government possesses in the valleys of the two rivers an extraordinarily valuable property, capable of great development, and in the interests of the historical lands and of the Turkish Government itself we trust that H.M. the Sultan will see his way to allow the country to be developed with European capital,

div.head: THE BRITISH BUDGET. TEA DUTY REDUCED. AN UNSATISFACTORY YEAR.

div.p: House of Commons— The budget surplus for 1904-1905 is £1,414,000. The estimated surplus for 1905-1906 is £2,972,000. The budget reduced the tax on tea by two pence on the lb after the 1st July. The sugar and income taxes remain unchanged. A Considerable portion of the surplus is to be devoted towards redeeming the national debt. Mr. Austen Chamberlain said the past year had been an unsatisfactory one both commercially and financially. The revenue on sugar promised to be an expanding one. The revenue on tea was £210,000 short of the estimate chiefly owning the merchant holding their supplies back during the past quarter, in the hope of a reduction in the duty. The consumption of spirits and beer was steadily diminishing. He had reduced the tax on tea because the article was one of daily consumption in every household and came mainly from the British colonies. (Reuter.)

div.head: THE COMING SEA FIGHT. WHEREABOUTS OF FLEETS.

div.p: The Russian fleet is expected at Batavia. (Havas.) Singapore, April 10. Rear Admiral Enquist was in command of the Baltic Fleet which passed here. A steamer has sighted Admiral Enquist's squadron at anchor 150 miles from Singapore. Four Japanese warships were sighted off Cape St. Jaques on the 7th inst. (Reuter.) Batavia, April 11. Presumably Admiral Rodjestvensky with most of his battleships is at Muntok (Banca Island). (Reuter.)

The report that the Russian frontier guard on the Upper Oxus has been detached to reinforce the Kushk garrison is denied here. It is added that the troops hitherto at Merv will remain there. No troops have arrived in Turkestan from Orenburg except some Cossack reliefs. (Reuter.)
The lieutenant in charge of the surveillance of the frontier yesterday chased away some bands of the Pretender who were attacking the Moorish troops near Oudja. (Havas.)

div.head: INSURRECTION IN CRETE SITUATION BECOMING WORSE.

div.p: The situation is becoming worse. The insurrection is spreading. (Havas.)

div.head: The "Journal Du Caire."
div.p: - M. Fernand Braun, of the Berlitz Schools, has taken over the Alexandria service of this newspaper.

div.head: NEW DOCTORS
div.p: - M. Evanghelle, Magnis, Salomon Khouri, and M. Louis Benzes, physicians, have been authorized to practice in Egypt.

div.head: THE PLAGUE
div.p: - During last week four cases of plague were reported throughout Egypt; one at Alexandria, two at Tant el-Ghezireh, and one at Maghagha.

div.head: SANITARY DEPT.
div.p: - Dr. Percy G.S. Williams, of London, has been appointed assistant inspector to the Sanitary Department at a salary of L.E 360 a year.

div.head: THE HOTEL SANATORIUM,
div.p: Al Hayat, at Helouan, will not remain open for the whole summer, as last year, but will close its doors on the 20th May.

div.head: UM RUS GOLD MINES OF EGYPT (Ltd.)
div.p: - The first batch of allotment letters in respect of the new issue of shares of this company has been posted from London.

div.head: THE FRENCH CRUISER
div.p: "Ensernet" arrived at Suez yesterday from Djibouti, and will probably return to that port after a short stay there. She carries 17 guns, and a crew of 275 men all told.

div.head: THE GREAT NUMBER
div.p: of tourists who have busted Egypt this season, has has the result of flooding Sicily with visitors on their return to Europe. Taormina is at the present moment crammed with visitors.

div.head: CATTLE PLAGUE
div.p: - The following are the localities where deaths from cattle plague occurred last week: 14 at Mina-el-Kamh, 19 at Zagazig, 3 at bit Ghamr, 1 at Chibine el-Kom, 2 at Menouf, 2 at Ghizeh, and 1 at Embabeh.

div.head: PRINCE COLIBRI,
div.p: who is said to be the smallest man on earth, has come down to Alexandria after a most successful season in Cairo, and will be on view fro, tomorrow at 5pm, in a room adjoining the Alhambra Theatre.

H.M.S. "Diadem," for China, and the French cruiser "Chateaurenault," for Cherbourg, left Port Said yesterday. The "Diadem" has arrived at Suez, where she will remain several days for coaling purposes. She will take about 1,500 tons of coal.

div.head: KASR El-Nil Bridge
div.p: - A credit of L.E. 600 has been opened for moving the overhead telegraph wires that go along Kasr el-Nil bridge. These wires are to be taken under the river bed and will not therefore be liable to any injury owing to the opening of the bridge.

div.head: ZEITOUN.
div.p: -The roads in Zeitoun (writes a correspondent) are in a deplorable condition. This state of the roads causes much needless cruelty to animals dragging loads of stones, coal, petroleum, etc. It is to be hoped that the attention of the Tanzim Department will be drawn to the fact.

div.head: THE LOTTERY LAW.
div.p: - The Alexandria Gouvernorat was besieged this morning by crowds of street lottery ticket vendors, who complained of the conduct of the police in stopping their means of livelihood. The authorities of the Gouvernourat replied that the police were only carrying out the law.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN DIRECTORY
div.p: for 1905 (Rizzo & co., Cairo) is a great improvement on its predecessors, and judging by appearances this eminently useful publication has come to stay. It is exceedingly well got up and is replete with all that information which is usually to be found in a first-class directory. All the provincial towns of Egypt are included, also the Sudan.

div.head: CAIRO IMPROVEMENTS.
div.p: - Considerable improvements are to be made in Cairo. The Sharia Abbas is to be carried long the old track of the Matarieh railway line and thence to Kasr el-Nil Bridge. This scheme will give an open highway, free form the heavy traffic in the central part of the city, from Koubbeh Palace and Abbassieh, as well as from the Cairo railway station to Kasr el-Doubara, etc.

div.head: THE LAST HOMEWARD TRANSPORT
div.p: of the season,the "Sicilia" (Capt. G.H.G. Weston, R.N.R), arrived at Port Said yesterday morning from Bombay for Malta and Southampton. The troops on board numbered 971, consisting of details and the 38th Brigade of the Royal Field Artillery, composed of the 24th, 34th and 72nd Batteries. The officer commanding is Lt. Col. Watkins, Royal Horse Artillery.

div.head: MENA HOUSE.
div.p: -The management of Mena House Hotel are offering special terms to residents desirous of spending the Easter holidays there, and no doubt a great number will avail themselves of this opportunity to spend a few pleasant days at the pyramid. Despite the advanced season the hotel is still nearly full, and on Sunday last, at luncheon time, the big dining hall has the appearance of being in the height of the season. In the evening again, many drove out to dine and spend the evening inhaling the delicious fresh air of the desert.

div.head: THE BELGIAN CLUB
div.p: at Alexandria et on Saturday, on the occasion of the 70th birthday of the King of the Belgians, and despatched the following telegram, to his Majesty at Brussels: "Reunis occasion soixante duxueme anniversaire, the presents respectueuses felicitations." The following reply was received from the King's secretary, M. Carton de Wiart:- "Le row me charge de remercier la Colonie Belge de see sentiments partriotiques." The Belgian Club was founded two months ago and already numbers over fifty members. The premises of the club are temporarily located by the Place des Consuls.

div.head: BECK & CO'S PILSENER BEER
div.p: BREMEN.
Obtainable from every Respectable Firm In Cairo, Alexandria & the Sudan.
Otherwise apply to
V. J. FLEURENT, Cairo
F. MICALLEF, Sole Agent, 11 Bab Midan, Alexandria

div.head: ENGLISH PENSION, ITALIAN RIVIERA.
div.p: The best halfway home between Egypt and England is VIAREGGIO. near PISA.
Main line expresses stop. Fine woods, Sands, Sea bathing mild climate, English Pension, Villa Shelly. Ever home comfort. Electric light. Modern sanitation, Sunny aspect, close to sea and gardens.
Proprietress. English Ladies

div.head: TYROL.
div.p: Weissenstein Castle 3410 ft. First-class private hotel near Windisch-Matrei; Sation, Lienz (reached from Venice or Trieste). Good mountaineering centre. Tennis. Fishing, best June and September. Prospectuses and Photographs, "Egyptian Gazette" office, Cairo. 25365-48-28

div.head: THE ABYSSINIAN BANK. A LINK WITH EGYPT.
div.p: Writing from Adis Abeba on March 12, Reuter's agent says:- The consummation of the scheme for the establishment of a State Bank of Abyssinia is a triumph for Sir John Harrington, who has shown the Emperor Menelik very clearly the many advantages which such an institution in proper hands would secure to his country. I understand that the capital is to be apportioned as follows: one-half to the National Bank of Egypt, whose agent, Mr, McGil Ivray, has been here for the last month arranging the details; one quarter to an Italian group of financiers, and the remaining quarter to a French syndicate, under the auspices of M. Ilg. the Kings Conseiller d'Etat. There is a rumor here that Sir John Harrington has been offered an important position in the bank when it is established. His acceptance would be a serious loss to British diplomacy here, though an undoubted gain to the bank. Speaking if the National Bank of Egypt's monopoly in Abyssinnia, the "African world" says:- There is no doubt that by means of railroads and the Nile waterways a valuable trade route will be established sooner or later between Abyssinia , the Sudan, and Egypt.To Sir Ernest Cassel and the National Bank of Egypt is due the credit for taking a step which cannot fail to promote progress in this direction. Their scheme paves the way for the introduction on a large scale of British capital into Abyssinia, and provides an important financial link between the country and Egypt. French and Italian financiers certainly have a hand in the new Abyssinian Bank, but the National Bank of Egypt holds half the stock and is the controlling factor. The value if this is clear from the agreement, which gives the Abyssinian Bank a minting and banking monopoly for fifty years, with the right to issue bank notes and establish entrepôts throughout Abyssinia. The possibilities of such a monopoly, from the British point of view, are boundless, and Sir Ernest Cassel is to be congratulated on having carried through so important an enterprise.

div.head: EGYPTIAN TRUST AND INVESTMENT.
div.p: Extraordinary scenes were witnessed yesterday at the Anglo Egyptian Bank at Alexandria, on the occasion of the subscription to the issue of the Egyptian Trust and Investment, Limited. The subscription opened at 9am. and by 11 a.m. the capital of the company (£200,000) had been covered forty times over. At midday, when the bank closes, hundreds of persons were still waiting to put in their applications, and the bank was thronged with an excited crowd all through the afternoon. The struggle to get to the counter was very keen, and even when the bank closed in the evening hundreds of would-be investors had not yet sent in their applications. Before the bank opened this morning crowds were gathering a the doors, and in the course of the forenoon the applications were coming in in such vast numbers that it was decided to close the list at midday today. Telegrams from London state that the applications have been very numerous, and at Cairo alone the capital has been subscribed several times over. The management in Egypt has decided to work day and night in order to complete the allotment, and to be in a position to return the surplus cheques, at an early date.

div.head: CORPORATION OF WESTERN EGYPT.
div.p: In reference to our paragraph of Saturday, the engineer in charge class from El Der in the Oasis of Kharga that water has been struck at a depth of 145 feet in the first bore-hole put down, a plentiful supply being now available. The option of acquiring the land adjacent to the bore-hole will be exercised by the corporation forthwith as part of the 20,000 fed dans which they are entitles to take up under their concessions from the Egyptian Government annually for 30 years. A most favorable agreements has been entered into with the omdehs and sheikhs of the Kharga Oasis relative to the boring of wells and supply of water on locally owned lands.

div.head: EXPORT OF GUM ARABIC.
div.p: During the month of february, 849,806 kilos of gu, arabic, valued at L.E. 19,121, were exported from Egypt. In the same month of 1901, the exports were 617,408 kilos, of the value of L.E. 13,889; an increase in 1905 of 232,398 kilos value L.E. 5,232. From the first of January to the 28h of February 1905 the exports to Englands and her Mediterranean possessions were 259,649 kilos, value L.E.5,842. Germany, 283,423 kilos, value L.E. 6,377. Austria-Hungary, 129,773 kilos, value L.E. 2,921. France and Algeria, 310,799 kilos, value L.E. 6993. Italy, 57,250 kilos, value L.E. 1,289. turkey, 1,487 kilos, value L.E. 33. America, 123,844 kilos, value L.E. 2,787; and to other countries 233,813 kilos, value L.E. 5,261; an increase over 1904 of 484,902 kilos, value L.E. 10,916.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The S.S. "Cyprian Prince," from Antwerp and London, left Malta on Saturday last and is due here on Wednesday next, with passengers and general cargo. The Ellerman S.S. "Flaminian" arrived at Liverpool from Alexandria on Sunday.

div.head: THE PENNY POST. SUGGESTED EXTENSIONS TO EGYPT.
div.p: The Postmaster General is to be asked by Mr. Henniker-Heaton, M.P. whether he will open negotiations with the Egyptian authorities for the extension of the penny post to Egypt.

div.head: EGYPTS TRADE. CUSTOM RETURNS FOR FEBRUARY.
div.p: The imports into Egypt during February last are values at L.E. 1,385,341, this being an increase on the corresponding month of last year of L.E. 131,074. From the 1st January to 28th February the imports amounted to L.E. 3,164,448, an increase of nearly half a million on the figures for the first two months of last year. In this increase, it is not very satisfactory to find that the United Kingdom only shares to the extent of L.E. 77,429. it is, however, a better record than last year, when British imports declined by L.E. 75,810 for the first two months of the year. There was also but a very small augmentation in the imports from British possessions in the Mediterranean, which amounted to L.e. 27,945, as against L.E. 24,507. Imports from British possessions in the Far East declined considerably, from L.e> 169,647 to L.E. 135,153. While British exports to Egypt make but a poor showing during the first two months of the year, every other country has profited by the increased trade of Egypt. America particularly has nearly doubled her exports to Egypt, the figures for that country having risen from L.E. 28,473 to LE 55,945. German imports increased by L.E. 33,801, French by L.E. 68,277, Belgian by L.E. 13,744, Austrian by L.E. 11,498, Italian by L.E. 26,822, Russian by L.E. 81,914, and Turkish by L.E. 25,425.

div.head: STATE RAILWAY CONTRACTS.
div.p: With regard to the new rolling stock we hear from a well-informed source that one or more of a new consignment of trucks, supplied by a Belgian firm, have derailed on a curve near Alexandria, which is reputed to be the sharpest on the whole State railway system. The last consignment of trucks, received from a British firm in September, 1904, did precisely tho same thing. A very slight alteration set the British trucks right, and it is believed that the Belgian trucks, of which there are fifty of the type in question, can be altered as easily. The Belgian firm concerned has supplied tho state Rail- ways Administration with large numbers of trucks, which have proved very satisfactory and are not dear. We hear, however, that the Railway Administration has given the last order fur trucks to a good British firm whose price is a little higher. The Belgian company is said to have been a little careless over this particular contract, and the placing of the latest order with a British firm may be regarded as a hint to" tho company to take tho greatest possible trouble over the fulfillment of the con- tracts that may be given them in future. In this connection our readers will be in- terested to bear that the Finance Ministry has opened credits of over three-quarters of a million to be spent on the railways, of which L.B. 420,000 are for the purchase of new rolling stook.

div.head: SUMMER ROTATIONS.
div.p: Summer rotations on canals in the Delta will commence on the 1st May. The first programme will allow six days working followed by fifteen days stoppage for outlets and lifting machines, and four days working follow- ed by five and six days stoppage on canals irrigating rice. The programmes will be pub- lished shortly.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive spent yesterday on his estates at Mariout and returned to Montazah Palace , in the evening. His Highness will not return to Cairo before Saturday next,as he will on that day inaugurate tho Horticultural Show at San Stofano. The date of his Highness's final departure from the Capital for the summer will be pub- lished shortly in the "Official Journal."

div.head: THE DUKE OF THE ABRUZZI.
div.p: The Duke of the Abruzzi was entertained to lunch yesterday at the Mohamed Aly Club by the acting Italian Consul, Sig. Monzani. This morning at 10 o'clock His Royal High- ness, accompanied by Sig. Monzani, visited the Italian-Schools and the Banco di Roma, where he was received by the director, M. de Beaupuis, and some Italian capitalists. The Duke afterwards assisted at the inau- guration of a flagstaff at the headquarters of the Italian Mutual Aid Society. His Royal Highness will hold a reception of the Italian colony to-morrow afternoon, from 4 to 5, on the "Liguria." The "Liguria" will probably leave Alexandria on Thursday morning. The crew of the "Liguria" disembarked yesterday evening and were received by the members of various Italian clubs and societies on the quay. The latter afterwards escorted the sailors through the town in a torchlight procession to the Alhambra Theatre, where they were entertained.
Anglo-American Nile Steamer & Hotel Company
River Transport of Good Between Alexandria & Cairo
Three Sailings a-Week.
Agents at Alexandria:
Alexandria Bonded Warehouse Co. Ld

div.head: THE POLYTECHNIC COLLEGE. SCHOOL DESERTED.
div.p: We bear that the pupils out on strike have received a letter from the head master of the Polytechnic College suspending them for a week. They have replied that they will not return to the college at all unless better terms are offered, and meantime the school is deserted. The parents of the boys who have left the school have received notices from the head master informing them that if their sons do not return within a week they will all be expelled for good. The boys have already informed the authorities of the school that they will not return at all unless their demands are complied with. The present situation therefore is of a threatening character, and we hope that some way out of the difficulty will be discovered. We are informed that "Maison a louer" has been chalked up on the school gate.

div.head: GENERAL ASSEMBLY.
div.p: The following were the resolutions adopted by the General Assembly on Sunday :— 1. That the modification of 'hodjeta' should be untaxed when the hods had been modified in consequence of the Survey Department's operations ; proposed by Sidky Pasha. 2. That the Helouan Railway should be carried on to the El Saff district, north of Atfeh ; proposed by Moh. Eff. el Miligni. 3. That 'sefi' irrigation should be extended to the eastern part of Ghizeh Province. 4. That the provincial councils should be charged with tge work undertaken by the Meglis el Hasbi and the commission of sheikhs; proposed by Ibrahim Bey Murad. 5. That the Mehkemeh Sharieh should be reformed, their cadis and functionaries better paid, the judges chosen for merit and offices found worthy of the Mehkemeh Courts; by Ibrahim Bey Mourad. 6. That omdehs and sheikhs, when brought before councils of discipline, should be allowed professional legal assistance, and should be able to appeal against the judgments of those councils ; by Osman Bey Mourad.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL DECORATIONS.
div.p: The Khedive has been pleased to bestow the following decorations and ranks:- Osmanieh. Grand Cordon (1st class): Bakaa Essaltana Mirza Aly Azghar Khan, Consul-General for Persia in Egypt. Grand Officer (2nd class); Zaim Eddawlah, Docteur Mirza Mohamed Mahdy Khan Rais- el-Hokama. Medjidieh. Grand Officer (2nd class) : Mihran Khan, Persian Consul at Alexandria. Commander (3rd class) : Kamel Taymour Bey, notable of Alexandria, and Frederic Bo- nola Bey, secretaryf the Khedivial Geogra- phical Society. Officer (4th class) Taeb Bey, secretary of the Consulate General of Persia, and Aka Mo- hamed Aly, moein ettoggar. Mirmiran. . Seifoullah Youssri Pasha, notable of Cairo, and Hussein Chahine Pasha, notable of Cairo. Moutamaiz. Ahmed El-Alfy Bey, notable of Charkiee, and Mansour Abou Hussein Bey, notable of Menoufieh. Sanieh. Mahrouss Ismail Bey, notable of Beni-Souef, Docteur Mohamed Amin Azab Bey, doctor at Zagazig, Gad Mahgoub El-Heut Bey, notable of Charkieh, Saleh Echawarbi Bey, notable of Galioub, Haroun Badawi Echawarbi Bey, no- table of Galioub, Mansour Abed Boy, notable of Galioubieg, Boulos Hanna El-Kichtah Bey, notable of the district of Samalout, Ghibrial Moussa Bey, notable of Menoufieh, Daoud Ammoun Bey, advocate in Cairo, Imam Fahmi Bqe, advocate in Assiout Salissah (with title of Bey): Mohamed Ibra- him Waly Bey, notable of Assiout, and Eakha- roun Ishak El-Mankabady Bey, notable of Sohag.

div.head: CHARITY BAZAAR.
div.p: A charity bazaar for the benefit of the proposed Israelite Hospital at Abbassieh was held on Sunday at MM. Cattaui's grounds in the Ismailieh quarter of Cairo. The sales went off excellently, the kiosks being besieged by buyers. Miles E. Cattaui, N. Rossi, and R. Mosseri sold bric-a-brac; the teas were sold by Mile Aline Mosseri and Mile Leonie Curiel, while other refreshments were under the care of Miles L. Suares and J. Mondolfo. Mme Maurice Cattaui Bey presided over the lottery, and the Miles Gallico over the "petits chevaux." Among the many buyers were Count B. de Kosziebrodzki, M. von Hahn, Mr. Riddle, Mme and the Miles de Villebois, Mme De Martino, M. and Mme A. Cattaui, M. and Mme Rolo,| Mme Naggar, Mme Ismalun, M. and Mme Chalom, and many well-known members of the Israelite community of Cairo. The Bracale Orchestra played throughout the sale.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Auiourrdhui d midi et demit)

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Prince and Princess Arisugawa of Japan are due at Port Said on the 6th proxo. by the North German Lloyd "Prinz Heinrich." Lady Cromer's brother, Lord Alexander Thynne, who is homeward bound from the Cape on the "Walmer Castle," has been for the best part of the last three years private secre- tary to Sir Hamilton Gould-Adams, Lieutenant- Governor of the Orange River Colony. He represented the City of London on the London County Council till 1900, when he went to South Africa with the Imperial Yeomanry. Lord Alexander, who is the Marquees of Bath's only brother, is thirty-two, adfine rider, and a splendid shot, and is likely to be offered a high post in the new South African Colonies. The Right Reverend Bishop Morley, D.D, Archdeacon of the Church of England in Egypt, left yesterday with Mrs. Morley by the Austrian Lloyd s.S. "Bohemia" for Venice whence he will go to Moran to take a chaplaincy until June, when he will proceed to England. M. Maximoff, Russian Consul-General in Cairo, has come down to Alexandria and is staying at the Carlton Hotel, Bulkeley. M. Maximoff will be shortly leaving Egypt permanently in order to represent Russia at Cettinje. We also notice amongst the latest arrivals at the Carlton Mr. and Mrs. Meimarachi, Mr. Alf. Chamass, Mr. H. Wilson, Mr. and Mrs. Adamopoulos, Mrs. Mille, Mrs. Boganos and companion, Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Mosseri, Dr. Mosseri, Mr. G. Bavastro, Mme. Vve. Sebah, Sir. Alex Dahan, Mr. Wm. Crosseley. Mr. A.S. Ades, Miss Cobb, Miss Adamson,Mr. R. Sidney Wright, and Mr. A.G.K. Levick. Mr. Vincent Corbett, the Financial Adviser returned to Cairo yesterday. Baron Max Oppenheim, secretary of legation for Germany in Cairo, left yesterday for Algiers as delegate of the German Empire at the International Congress of Orientalists. Mr. Maurice Sheldon Amos, judge at the Native Tribunal of First Instance of Cairo, passed the advanced examination in Arabic held on April 4, 5, 6 and 8. The following are the names of the Coun- sellors of the Court of Appeal who were present at the banquet given in Shepheard's Hotel on Saturday in honor of Judge Coghlan : — Saleh Sabit Pasha, Mr. Bond, Mr. Holtz, Afifi Bey, Hanna Bey, Mr. Willmore, Magdi Bey, Yehia Bey, KaasemBey, Saad Bey, Chawky Bey, Zoolficar Bey, Mr. Halton, Mr. Royle, Mr. Dilberoglne, Mr. Perry, Mr. Satow, Ziwer Bey, Helmy Bey, Kahil Bey, Mchrez,Bey, and Said Bey. The Khedive has promoted Mohamed Tewfik Chehabeddin Bey, of Belcas, to the rank of Sanieh.

div.head: ST. MARK'S, ALEXANDRIA. "THE HOLY CITY."
div.p: It is proposed to render this remarkably popular work by an augmented choir in St. Mark's Church on Tuesday, 25th inst., at 5.45 m. "The Holy City" is a sacred cantata, com- posed for the Birmingham Musical Festival in 1882 by Alfred R Gaul, Mus. Bac. Cantab., organistand choirmaster of 8t Augustine's Church, Edgbaston. Mr. Gault cantatas have attained a greater popularity with amateur choral societies than those of any other com- poser. It is interesting to mention that his music has been performed in Persia, Rus- sia, China, India, South America, South Africa, the United States of America, France, and most of the English colonies. Like all his cantatas, "The Holy City" appeals succesfully to those who love choral sing- ing, and who take an interest in sacred nar- ratives set to thoroughly singable music which can at once be appreciated. With the exception of two hymns ("No shadows yonder by Horatius Bonar, and "For thee, O dear, dear country," by J.M. Neale), a verse from Milton's poem 'At a Solemn Music' ("List l the Cherubic Host,") and three verses from the Te Deum, the words are entirely scriptural and are admirably chosen. The work consists of the prologue (added by the composer in 1901), an obviously appropriate and beautiful introduction. Part I. "Contemplation" is the fundamental note in the treatment of the subject, which is suggested by the following passages of Scrip- ture: "Here we have no continuing city." "Thy kingdom come." The desire for a higher and better life is expressed in the words of a tenor solo, "My soul is athirst for God." In Part II " Adoration " is the ketnote. The subject is announced in a bass solo, "I saw a new heaven and a new earth," with its pianissimo "Sanotus" sang as a chorus. The desire and pro- mises of Part I. are represented are realised in Part II. The whole cantata is an uninterrupted flow of charming melody and effective choral writing. To the choir of St. Mark's, and to those who assist them, lovers of sacred music will be grateful for introducing to Alexandria this deservedly popular work. The rendering of the cantata will occupy not more than 1 1/6 hour. Those present will be invited to contribute towards the expense incurred by the choir in purchasing the music, hiring a piano, etc.

div.head: LA QUESTION DES THEATRES
div.p: Monsieur le Directeur

de "l'Egyptian Gazette" Permettez-moi d'abord dé vous remercier de la publication dans votre estimable journal de l'interview que j'ai eu avec un de vos rédac teurs à propos de l'emplacement d'un grand théâtre d'opéra.

Bien que je pus m'attendre à l'approbation de tous les cercles compétents dans une question qui touche de si près à l'avenir et à l'em bellissement de la ville d'Alexandrie, je n'osai、 espérer pour ma proposition un accueil aussi chaleureux et aussi unanime; ce qui prouve combien l'idée de construire un superbe théâtre sur la place occupée par l'ancienne gare de Ramleh est heureuse et conforme tant aux intérêts des habitants qu'aux lois de l'esthé tique.

Lorsque, en effet, vous remontez le boulevard de Ramleh pour prendre le tram de San Stefano, vous découvrez maintenant l'horizon là où se trouvait jadis la gare de Ramleh. Le sol y est de cinq mètres plus élevé qu'à la ! place des consuls et domine tout un réseau de rues et de boulevards. On peut s'imaginer co qu'un édifice monumental attirant du plus loin le regard aurait là de majestueux. Cette situation avait tellement frappé les anciens qu'ils y avaient érigé le fameux palais des Césars.

Qu'on ne me vienne pas dire que cela dé tournera la ligne des trams. Ceux-ci aboutissent en ligne droite à la Tour des Romains et c'est grâce à un détour qu'on les a rejoint au bouleva vard de Ramleh. En redressant la direction, on obtiendra un espace libre de cent mètres de largeur sur cent mètres de longueur; mais comme toute la beauté de l'édifice réside en ce e toute que le milieu de la façade monumentale corresponde éxatement au milieu du boulevard de Ramleh où elle charmera l'oeil du promeneur sur tout le parcours, et que d'autre part tout le terrain nécessaire n'appartient pas à la Munici palité, il faudra empiéter sur la propriété privée.

Supposons que la façade ait 50 mètres de large. En faisant coincider le milieu de la façade avec le milieu du boulevard, on voit que la ville ne dispose que de 35 mètres. Le reste, soit 15 mètres, appartient à M. Casulli. Celui-ci devra donc céder à la ville 15 mètres pour le théâtre et 20 autres pour l'isoler, soit en tout un lot de 35 mètres de large sur une longueur de 100 mètres. Le prolongement de la rue Pereira, qui s'impose, servira à isoler l'édifice du côté de Ramleh. De cette manière la ville disposera d'un terrain libre de 5,000 mètres carrés, fimités du côté nord par les terrains de la Municipalité, du côté Est par le prolongement de la Rue Pereira, du côté Sud par une rue de 20 mètres de large, et du côté Ouest par le boulevard de Ramleh et la rue Missala. La port cédée par M. Casulli serait de 4,450 m2. dont 35m. X 100 n. soit 3,500 m2. sur le côté sud et 950 m2. pour l'ouverture de la rue Pereira. De ces 4,450 m2. il faut déduire un excédent de 850 m2 cédé à Casulli pour l'alignement. Le reste, soit 3,600 m2. serait compensé en terrains appartenant à la Municipalité.

La ville n'aurait donc rien à payer pour le terrain et tout l'argent disponible pourrait être affecté à l'embellissement du théâtre dont l'ar- chitecture ferait l'orgueil d'Alexandrie. Notre ville se montrerait ainsi la digne émule de l'ancienne capitale des Ptolémées et des Césars. G. ZOURO

div.head: Vente de biens wakfs
div.p: Nous lisons dans le "Lewa" de samedi passé :

" Jeudi matin a eu lieu, à la direction générale des Wakfs, en présence de quelques financiers, la mise en vente aux enchères des wakfs particuliers Aly pacha Chérif et Mouekli pacha, situés dans l'ile de Rhoda.

"La mise à prix par feddan était de 1,300 L.E. L'adjudication a duré jusqu'à une heure de l'après-midi, MM. Zervudachi et Cie ayant offert jusqu'à 1,360 L.E. par feddan, ont ob tenu ces terrains, en échange de ceux situés à Ragdieh, dans la province de Gharbieh, évalués à 150 L.E. par feddan.
"L'affaire sera soumise en dernier ressort au grand Cadi, qui approuvera ou annulera l'échange fait dans ces conditions.'

div.head: The Egyptian Salt & Soda Company Ltd.
div.p: NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN that an Extraordinary General Meeting of the above named Company will be held at the National Bank of Egypt in Cairo on Saturday the 22nd day of April 1905 at 3 o'clock in the afternoon for the purposes following, that is to say:

1. To consider and it thought fit to confirm as a Special Resolution the subjoined Resolution which was passed by the requisite majority at the Extraordinary General Meeting of the Company held on the 7th day of April 1905, viz :

That Clause 10 of the Articles of Association of the Company be altered so that paragraph (A) thereof shall run as follows that is to say: A. The profits of the Company which in respect of each year shall be available for dividend as certified by the auditors shall be applicable First in making such provision for a reserve and depreciation fund as the Directors shall think fit And Secondly in paying into a special dividend fund such a sum as shall be sufficient to pay a dividend for such year at the rate of six per cent on the 300,000 Ordinary Shares in the original capital And Thirdly of the surplus Five per cent shall be applied in the payment of dividend on the said Deferred Shares And Fourthly of what remains a sum sufficient for the payment of a dividend for such year at the rate of six per cent on any additional Ordinary Shares in the capital of the Company which shall have been issued shall be carried to the said special dividend fund And Fifthly the residue of such surplus shall be applied to the payment of a further dividend on all classes of shares respectively other than the Deferred Shares. The said special fund shall be distributed amongst the holders of the Ordinary Shares whether in the original capital or in any increases of capital in proportion to the Ordinary Shares held by them respectively.

2. To consider and if thought fit pass an Extraordinary Resolution in accordance with Clause 48 of the Articles of Association to the effect that the capital of the Company be increased by the creation of 150,000 new Ordinary Shares of £1 each.
Dated the 10th day of April 1905.
By order of the Board, ALFRED LAMBART, SECRETARY TO THE BOARD.
Boulac, Cairo.

Shareholders holding Share Warrants to Bearer who wish to attend the above Meeting must first deposit their Bearer Warrants together with a statement of their names and addresses with any of the following Banks in Cairo or Alexandria, namely, the National Bank of Egypt, the Angle-Egyptian Bank, Limited, the Crédit Lyonnais, the Bank of Egypt Limited, the Imperial Ottoman Bank, two clear days before the date of the Meeting (viz, not later than the 19th day of April), the Share Warrants remaining so deposited until after the Meeting shall have been held. Each Depositor will receive a certificate of deposit and a ticket of admission (which) must be produced by the holder attending the Meeting) and a form of proxy. If the Depositor does not intend personally to attend the Meeting, a form of proxy in favor of the person producing the certificate must be lodged with the National Bank of Egypt in Cairo or Alexandria not less than 48 hours before the
Meeting.
A form of Proxy in favor of the Directors

will be sent to each registered' Shareholder. Shareholders who are unable to attend personally are requested to sign and return a form of proxy so as to reach the Chairman at least 48 hours before the Meeting, 25756-1

div.head: Municipalité d'Alexandrie
div.p: AVIS

Le mardi 18 avril ct. de 11 h.a.m. à 1 h. p.m. ét de 3 h. au coucher du soleil la Municipalité procédera à la vente aux enchères publiques près des cimetières européens sis à la Porte-Rosette, d'une quantité de 1000 m3 environ des pierres extraites des terrains des Fortifications divisée en lots de 40 à 100 m3.
N

Les acheteurs devront payer le droit d'en chère de 1% et déposer le 10 % de la valeur de la marchandise achetée, au moment de la vente et effectuer le paiement intégral à la J Caisse Municipale le lendemain du jour de l'adjudication.
Ils auront à supporter les droits de carrière au profit de la ville et devront enlever les pierres achetées dans un délai de dix jours, sous peine de folle enchère pour compte de l'adjudi-C cataire.
L'Administrateur,
(Signé) W. P. CHATAWAY.
Alexandrie, le 10 Avril 1905.

div.head: National Bank of Egypt.
div.p: AVIS AUX ACTIONNAIRES.

Messieurs les actionnaires de la National Bank of Egypt sont convoqués en Assemblée Générale Extraordinaire pour le Samedi six Mat 1905 à 4 heures de l'après-midi, au Siège Social, au Caire, afin de délibérer sur la proposition suivante :
Augmentation du Capital Social et modifica tion de l'article
10 des Statuts.

Tout actionnaire possédant au moins vingt actions a droit de prendre part à l'Assemblée Générale à condition de déposer ses notions dans l'un des lieux ci-après désignés où il lui sera délivré une carte d'admission.
En Egypte, Cinq jours au moins avant le le jour de la réunion, soit le 1er Mai, au plus tard:
au Siège Social, au Caire;
à la Succursale à Alexandrie;
à la Banque Impériale Ottomane; à l'Anglo- Egyptian Bank;
au Crédit Lyonnais;
à la Bank of Egypt;
au Caire
ou
à Alexandrie.
En Europé, au plus tard le 27 Avril:

à Paris et à Marseille, aux bureaux de la "Société Marseillaise"; en Italie, dans les bureaux de la "Banca Commerciale Italiana"; à Londres, à l'Agence de la National Bank of Egypt, 4 et 5. King William Street. E.C. L'Assemblée, pour pouvoir délibérer valablement devant réunir la moitié des actions émises, Messieurs les actionnaires sont priés de faire le dépôt de toutes leurs actions.
Le Gouverneur:
Le Caire, le 5 Avril 1905.
Elwin Palmer.

COTON-Nouvelle recolte: Demandee, mais addaires restreintes, faute de vendeurs. Cours tres fermes.

Recolte nxxmelle: Eu commerve a achere dans l'aores-midi et cela a contribue a raffermir les cours. En cloture nous acons au une legere reaction, mais quand meme nous resions en benefice de 7/82 sur la coture de 1 heure.

REMARQUES
Cotons: Nouvelle récolte.—Le novembre a ouvert à 14 15/16 sous l'impression de la clôture d'Amérique et ne tarde même pas à fléchir à 14 7/8, mais il se raffermit de nouveau. Affaires claisemées.
Récolte actuelle. —Juillet a débuté à 14 5/16 et reste soutenu. Marché peu animé.
Grains de coton: Nouvelle récolte.— Sans affaires importante; quand même les cours sont bien tenus.
Récolte actuelle.—Juillet a obtenu P.T. 58 ¾ à l'ouverture.
Fèves-Saidi: Nouvelle récolte.—Marché nul.
